question_details.query: What is the most cost-effective method for improving soil fertility in Mediterranean arable fields: adding compost or growing cover crops?

summary_details.relevant_summary: In Mediterranean-type climates and countries including Italy and Spain, winter cover crops increased soil organic matter in some or all comparisons across a meta-analysis and multiple replicated, controlled studies, and increased soil nitrogen in some comparisons, though other studies found less or inconsistent nitrogen changes; phosphorus was similar in one study, potassium increased in one study; cover crops also increased microbial biomass and water-stable aggregates in some comparisons [1345]. Across studies from Italy, Spain, Syria, and Turkey, adding compost increased soil organic matter in some or all comparisons and increased soil nutrients in some or all comparisons, with inconsistent nitrogen results and no difference in phosphorus in one study; pH was similar in some studies; compost increased microbial biomass in some or all comparisons and improved soil stability and reduced erosion in some studies [1362].

Adding compost increased soil nutrients in some or all comparisons.
